title: Coupling the Heart to Musical Machines
author: Eric Easthope (University of British Columbia)
relevance_why: The paper explores biofeedback control via heart rate, which could inform techniques for audio generation and manipulation, particularly in creating responses that align with human physiological signals.
background: This paper investigates using heart rate as a control mechanism in musical performance through a biofeedback loop involving the heartbeat and audio playback.
contribution: This work introduces a novel photoplethysmogram-based controller to manipulate sound in real-time by varying audio playback tempo according to heart rate.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous systems primarily used breath as a control input for musical interfaces, which limits the range of physiological signals exploited.
technical_comparison.novelty: This research extends the biofeedback paradigm to include heart rate, enabling more intimate and responsive audio control mechanisms.

key_innovation: The integration of heart rate feedback to dynamically adjust audio tempo in a real-time musical context introduces a fresh perspective on human-computer interaction.
real_world_impact: This controller could be useful in therapeutic music applications and interactive installations, enhancing user engagement and emotional response through music.
limitations: The paper does not extensively address the impact of real-world variability in heart rates or the physiological differences among users.

new_terms.photoplethysmogram: **Photoplethysmogram (PPG)** is a non-invasive method used to detect blood volume changes in the microvascular bed of tissue, often used for monitoring heart rate.
